awd_titl_txt: Physics at the Frontier: Collider and Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Wackeroth, Kinney, and Stojkovic at the State University of New York, University at Buffalo. 

The goal of this research project is to make important progress in providing answers to key open questions at the frontiers of particle physics, cosmology and gravity research, and in doing so to go significantly beyond the current state of the art in the field. New particle accelerators such as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and envisioned successors are probing new physics at the energy frontier and are capable of providing answers to important questions about the structure and history of the universe. On the other hand, cosmology provides a unique laboratory in which to study questions in physics inaccessible to traditional particle physics methods, and forms a valuable complement to accelerators. Our current understanding of the fundamental problems about the origin, evolution and future of our universe is still in its infancy, and a synthesis of many independent lines of evidence will be necessary to point the way to explanations. This project reflects that synergy, and promises to make significant progress in connecting high-precision cosmological and accelerator data to fundamental questions such as the origin and evolution of the universe, the unification of gravitation with quantum mechanics, the role of the vacuum in the structure of space and time. As a result, research in these areas advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. In addition, this project will involve graduate students and postdocs, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. The PIs will also continue presenting the latest scientific results to the public at large in the form of public talks and various outreach activities. Kinney will also continue organizing Science and Art Cabaret --- a unique mix of cutting-edge science and technology with art, music, poetry, and performance.

More technically, Wackeroth will concentrate on improving predictions for key SM measurements at the LHC by calculating higher-order QCD and electroweak corrections and implementing them in publicly available Monte Carlo event generators for realistic simulations. The comparison of experimental data with these improved predictions will probe the Standard Model with unprecedented precision and provide increased sensitivity to signals of new physics. The main thrust of Kinney's planned research for the next several years is to make quantitative connections between new observational Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) data and detailed properties of the early universe in order to address fundamental questions such as: What is the energy scale of cosmological inflation?  What is the form of the leading-order operator in the inflationary potential? Is the inflationary Lagrangian consistent with a simple canonical field theory? Is there evidence for quantum gravity effects, for example a Planck-scale cutoff in quantum modes? Can we explain CMB anomalies, such as the hemispherical asymmetry observed by Planck? Are there viable alternatives to inflation? What properties do they have?  Finally, Stojkovic will focus on LHC physics, in particular on further development of a comprehensive LHC event generator BlackMax which is extensively used by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations in search for exotic physics.

por.por_cntn:
The research completed under this grant focused on research by three faculty in the University at Buffalo (UB)  High-Energy Physics and Cosmology (HEPCOS) group: Stojkovic, Kinney, and Wackeroth. High energy physics broadly defined is aimed at understanding our universe from the smallest to the largest scales: The questions being asked are profound, ambitious and difficult. Answering them will take the concerted effort of many researchers over a span of many decades or more. Nonetheless, at least some of the answers appear to be within our reach. The nature of the problems treated is such that their resolution will inevitably involve different concepts from particle physics, gravitation and cosmology. Accordingly, the 2013 series of Snowmass workshops has identified a set of broadly defined ``Frontiers'' as priorities for future research: (1) The Energy Frontier, (2) The Intensity Frontier, and (3) the Cosmic Frontier. The research proposed here is closely focused on two of these priorities, the Energy and Cosmic Frontiers, and collaborative efforts will address the many regions of overlap between these broad categories. 

The research focused on connecting high-precision cosmological and accelerator data to fundamental questions such as the origin and evolution of the universe, the unification of gravitation with quantum mechanics, the role of the vacuum in the structure of space and time, and the nature of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. These are among the foremost unsolved issues facing physics in the twenty-first century, and this ``Physics of the Universe'' has been identified as a top NSF funding priority by the National Science and Technology Council Committee on Science. Among the questions addressed are:

  • How did the universe begin?
  • Why is the universe accelerating?
  • What is the dark matter?
  • Are there hints of physics beyond the Standard Model?

Kinney's research focused primarily on the interface between early universe cosmology and fundamental theories of particle physics. A major focus of research under this grant was recently proposed "swampland conjectures" relating theories of physics at low energy to string theory or other theories of quantum gravity. In particular, the widely studied theory of cosmological inflation, at least in its simplest form, is in significant tension with swampland conjectures. A second research focus was on the ``constant roll'' inflation scenario, which was pioneered in earlier work by Kinney, who studied the simplest example of ultra-slow roll inflation. These models are significant especially because they are a mechanism for generating primordial black holes in the early universe, which are a candidate for the (as yet unidentified) cosmological dark matter, which makes up around 25% of cosmological density. 

Stojkovic maintained and updated the event generator BlackMax, so that the members of the ATLAS, CMS and MOEDAL collaborations, as well as any other interested users can use the generator smoothly as other supporting and complementary software keep evolving. The new version of the manual and the software are published in a leading journal that specializes in physics software Comput.Phys.Commun. 236 (2019) 285-301. Both the paper and its associated computer program are available via the Computer Physics Communication homepage on ScienceDirect (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/00104655).

Wackeroth's research focus is concerned with the interpretation of experimental observations to gain insight in the fundamental interactions of the elementary constituents of matter, leptons and quarks, of particles which mediate the fundamental forces of nature, photons, W, Z bosons and gluons, and since recently also of the Higgs boson. Since the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the focus of future runs and upgrades of the LHC as well as the motivation for possible future high-energy colliders, is to precisely determine the properties of this new particle and to search for signals of non-standard physics, i.e. beyond those described by the Standard Model (SM). While direct signals of Beyond-the-SM (BSM) physics, i.e. the productions of new, massive particles, may require collider energies not yet accessible, it is possible that BSM physics first manifest itself in minute deviations in the comparison of precision data and their SM predictions due to the presence of BSM particles in quantum-loop corrections. It is therefore of the utmost importance that SM predictions are under superb theoretical control which requires the calculation of higher order corrections in perturbation theory. This grant supported calculations of these corrections in QCD and EW theory for key SM processes which are being precisely studied at the LHC, such as hadronic Z+b-jet production, single W and Z boson production and triple gauge-boson production.

Broader impacts included research training for both graduate and undergraduate students, as well as numerous conference presentations and public talks. Among the notable outreach efforts completed during the period of this grant was the continuation of the successful "Science & Art Cabaret" event, which has shown enduring public appeal, with ten events held during the life of this award.
